It's supposed to die once the stub is destroyed (and any outstanding calls
finished): my reading of your code says it's doing the right thing, so this
is a bug.

On Thu, Oct 15, 2015 at 1:55 PM Pavel Odintsov notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Hello!
> 
> I have implemented gRPC server and client.
> 
> But after client's app finished connection is not closed correctly:

Hello!

I have pulled recent commit e5cdbea1530a99a95fd3d032e7d69a19c61a0d16.

And bug still reproduces:

``` bash
root@filter /usr/src/gobgp/tools/grpc/cpp # LD_LIBRARY_PATH=".:/opt/grpc/lib:/opt/protobuf_3.0.0_alpha4/lib" ./gobgp_api_client
We received: Peer AS: 65001
Peer router id: 213.133.111.200

BGP state: BGP_FSM_ESTABLISHED
root@filter /usr/src/gobgp/tools/grpc/cpp # netstat -apnt|grep 8080
tcp6       0      0 :::8080                 :::*                    LISTEN      4504/gobgpd     
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44282         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
root@filter /usr/src/gobgp/tools/grpc/cpp # LD_LIBRARY_PATH=".:/opt/grpc/lib:/opt/protobuf_3.0.0_alpha4/lib" ./gobgp_api_client
We received: Peer AS: 65001

tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44282         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44283         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
root@filter /usr/src/gobgp/tools/grpc/cpp # LD_LIBRARY_PATH=".:/opt/grpc/lib:/opt/protobuf_3.0.0_alpha4/lib" ./gobgp_api_client
We received: Peer AS: 65001

tcp6       0      0 :::8080                 :::*                    LISTEN      4504/gobgpd     
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44282         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44283         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -

We received: Peer AS: 65001

Peer flops: 0
BGP state: BGP_FSM_ESTABLISHED
root@filter /usr/src/gobgp/tools/grpc/cpp # netstat -apnt|grep 8080
tcp6       0      0 :::8080                 :::*                    LISTEN      4504/gobgpd     
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44282         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44285         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp6       0      0 127.0.0.1:44283         127.0.0.1:8080          TIME_WAIT   -

```

If we are talking about the state `TIME_WAIT`, I think it's not caused by an improper closing of the connection. According to [RFC 793](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793#page-23), the active closer has to stay in `TIME-WAIT` for 2MSL when closing the connection. It seems a socket in `TIME-WAIT` cannot be forcibly closed.

Netcat gives the same result.

```
$ nc -l -k 50051 &
[1] 63077
$ echo "foo" | nc localhost 50051 -q 1
foo
$ echo "foo" | nc localhost 50051 -q 1
foo
$ echo "foo" | nc localhost 50051 -q 1
foo
$ netstat -apnt | grep 50051
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:50051           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      63077/nc        
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:57831         127.0.0.1:50051         TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:57835         127.0.0.1:50051         TIME_WAIT   -               
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:57837         127.0.0.1:50051         TIME_WAIT   -  
```

Other references: [Normal Close Sequence](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793#page-39) in RFC 793
